title: What a $15 Minimum Wage Will Really Do
sub_head: Raising the minimum wage to $15 per hour would greatly hurt the economy, and the young and underqualified will be the ones to suffer if this is enacted.
body:
Regarding your editorial “Reality Check for a $15 Minimum Wage” (Feb. 9): Raising the minimum wage to $15 per hour would greatly hurt the economy, and the young and underqualified will be the ones to suffer if this is enacted.
I have been employed by a nonprofit gymnastics association for the past five years (since I was 14). As a student instructor (until high-school graduation) I made $7.25 an hour. An organization like the one I work for employs mostly students ages 14-18. Raising the minimum wage to $15 per hour would result in a reduction of staff, so much so that the services we provide wouldn’t be able to adequately be performed, ultimately leading to the demise of the organization.
Many of the employment opportunities my college-student peers and I seek are part-time and require little to no experience. These opportunities will disappear if the minimum wage is increased to $15 per hour. With that in mind, it is likely that America will see a decrease in employment and increase in poverty among young adults and inexperienced workers.
For the sake of the small businesses and the young and inexperienced workers, the proposal of a $15 per hour minimum wage needs to be fought and ultimately rejected.
Leah Bookser
